Award.AwardTitle: New Directions in Law and Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Law and society scholarship is a vibrant field of study, encompassing a wide range of perspectives and addressing some of the most pressing questions facing society. These include salient issues such as the impact of technology on legal processes, efforts to redress violence from ongoing wars, understanding and overcoming bias in the legal system, and criminal justice reform. One of the challenges to solving these significant societal problems is that scholars addressing them frequently work independently from other scholars tackling the same issues from different disciplinary, methodological, or theoretical perspectives. Resolving highly significant and complex societal problems necessitates approaching those issues from a variety of perspectives, and requires scholarly exchange and collaboration.<br/> <br/>In order to encourage scholarly exchange, collaboration, and education, this grant will bring a diverse group of law and society scholars together for a conference at the University of Massachusetts Amherst from October 2-3, 2020. First, by facilitating opportunities for networking, scholarly exchange, and learning from panel presentations on funding and publishing law and society research, we plan to generate new research activity, highlight diverse forms of law and society research ranging from STEM to the humanities, and give concrete tools for academic advancement. Second, the conference will bring new scholars into the law and society research community, including women, scholars of color, and those from other underrepresented groups, inducting them into science research and helping to foster new research programs. Third, it will provide opportunities for graduate student training through a workshop in which graduate students will present their research and receive intensive feedback from senior scholars. Fourth, plenary sessions and critical intervention panels will be open to the public and will generate an edited volume, thus helping to inform public debate. Finally, we anticipate that participants will broadly disseminate the findings of the conference to their home institutions and in their teaching, thus expanding the conferenceâ€™s impact.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The New Directions in Law and Society grant funded two interdisciplinary academic conferences that generated new scholarship and promoted the training of graduate students and junior faculty members. A wide array of highly salient topic were discussed at these conferences, including immigration, criminal justice reform, legal decision making, and bias and inequality in the legal system.

The 2021 New Directions in Law and Society Virtual Graduate Student and Junior Scholar Workshop was held online on October 8-9, 2021 and featured 190 participants from across the country. The workshop provided graduate students and junior faculty members the opportunity to obtain detailed feedback on their research by pairing them mentors within a small group. The workshop also featured two professionalization panels on publishing in law and society (featuring editors of prominent journals in the field) and grants and funding (featuring an NSF Program Director and the Principle Investigator of the NSF Law and Science Dissertation Grant Program). It closed with plenary panel on the future of law and society featuring prominent senior scholars.

The 2022 New Directions in Law and Society Conference was held on October 7-8, 2022 at the University of Massachusetts Amherst and featured 110 participants from across the country. The conference featured a graduate student workshop where graduate students presented their research and were assigned a mentor to provide feedback, as well as traditional paper panels in which scholars presented their research on a panel of 4-5 paper presenters and received feedback from discussants and audience members. In addition, the conference featured two professionalization panels on publishing in law and society (featuring editors of prominent journals in the field) and grants and funding (featuring an NSF Program Director and the recipients of NSF grants). It also included two critical intervention panels on law and social exclusion and law, democracy, and authoritarianism, as well as two plenary panels that featured prominent senior scholars. 

 

The conferences have a great deal of intellectual merit. First, they brought together scholars from a variety of disciplinary, theoretical, and methodological perspectives to provide each other with constructive commentary on their research projects, which will aid them as they publish their research in peer-reviewed journals and books. Second, the conferences provided opportunities for networking among scholars studying law and society topics from a variety of approaches. This has the potential to form research collaborations that generate new research activity, including the development of new theories and the application of novel methodological approaches. Third, the conferences promoted grant-writing and publishing by offering professional development panels on these topics. Finally, the retreat generated original scholarship by the PIs, which is currently under peer review.

 

The conferences have several broader impacts. First, they brought new scholars into the law and society research community, including women, scholars of color, and those from other underrepresented groups, inducting them into science research and helping to foster new research programs. Second, they provided opportunities for graduate student training. This was accomplished primarily in the form of graduate student workshops in which graduate students presented their research and received intensive oral and written feedback from senior scholars, with whom they were be paired. Third, the plenary sessions and critical intervention panels were open to the public, thus helping to inform public debate about contemporary controversies such as bias in the legal system and law, democracy, and authoritarianism. Fourth, the co-PIs worked with an undergraduate student in planning the retreat, giving them real-life skills related to conference planning. Fifth, we anticipate that attendees will broadly disseminate what they learn at the retreat in their home institutions and beyond.
